instruction: What are the two basic design conditions for determining unequally-spaced channel frequencies in optical communication systems?
input:
Source: Firstly, it is necessary to meet the following two conditions. (1-1) Unequally-spaced channel frequencies should, as many as possible, be on the 100 GHz grid given in Annex A. If some channel frequencies cannot be on the grid, they should be within the rangeof the temperature control of lasers that meet the grid. Condition (1-1) aims to commonly use optical sources both in equally-spaced multichannel systems on G.652 and G.655 fibres and, in unequally-spaced multichannel systems on G.653 fibres. (1-2) Each unequally-spaced channel frequency should be chosen such that no new optical power generated by FWM fall into any optical signal channel. To meet (1-2), the channel spacing of any two channels must be different from that of any other pair of channels [1]. This is because the original signal frequencies fi, fj and fk and resultantFWM optical power frequency fijk are linked by the following equation: fijk–fi=fj–fk(i, j k) ≠(V-1)
Standard: G.692
output: The two basic design conditions are: (1) Unequally-spaced channel frequencies should, as many as possible, be on the 100 GHz grid. If some channel frequencies cannot be on the grid, they should be within the range of the temperature control of lasers that meet the grid. This condition aims to commonly use optical sources in both equally-spaced and unequally-spaced multichannel systems. (2) Each unequally-spaced channel frequency should be chosen such that no new optical power generated by Four-Wave Mixing (FWM) falls into any optical signal channel. This requires that the channel spacing of any two channels must be different from that of any other pair of channels to prevent FWM interference.

instruction: What is the minimum frequency slot required for 10 Gbit/s three-channel transmission to maintain penalties below 0.5 dB?
input:
Source: To determine signal frequencies, the minimum value of frequency slot should be first found out. To understand how to clarify the optimum 'minimum frequency slot' 10 Gbit/s, three-channel transmission is simulated as shown in Figure V.2 a). It is assumed that the three channels are externally modulated. The calculated penalty values against frequency slot are shown in Figure V.2 b) for the BER of 10^-12. The result indicates that frequency slot should be >20 GHz for penalties of <0.5 dB.
Standard: G.692
output: The minimum frequency slot required for 10 Gbit/s three-channel transmission to maintain penalties below 0.5 dB is greater than 20 GHz. This is determined through simulation of three externally modulated channels, with penalty values calculated against frequency slot for a bit error rate (BER) of 10^-12.

instruction: What is the impact of source frequency fluctuation on the frequency difference between an optical signal and the nearest FWM optical power?
input:
Source: Furthermore, when each optical signal frequency fluctuates by Δf, the frequency difference is reduced by 4 Δf, in the worst case as is understood from Equation V-1. If the source frequency fluctuation is suppressed to less than 1 GHz by using a frequency stabilisation [2], the frequency difference between the optical signal and the nearest FWM optical power is reduced from 24 GHz to20 GHz in the worst case as is understood from Equation V-1. Since the best frequency stabilityachievable with conventional technologies today is ~1 GHz, it is concluded that a quarter of the100 GHz grid spacing, or 25 GHz, is suitable as the minimum frequency slot.
Standard: G.692
output: When each optical signal frequency fluctuates by Δf, the frequency difference between the optical signal and the nearest FWM optical power is reduced by 4 Δf in the worst case. If the source frequency fluctuation is suppressed to less than 1 GHz using frequency stabilization, the frequency difference is reduced from 24 GHz to 20 GHz in the worst case. Given that the best frequency stability achievable with conventional technologies today is approximately 1 GHz, a quarter of the 100 GHz grid spacing, or 25 GHz, is considered suitable as the minimum frequency slot.

instruction: What are the design conditions for an unequally spaced frequency allocation with a 25 GHz slot in WDM systems?
input:
Source: The design conditions for an unequally spaced frequency allocation with 25 GHz slot are as follows: (2-1) The occupied optical bandwidth should be less than that of an 8-channel WDM system with 200 GHz equal channel spacing (11.2 nm) so that optical amplifiers with the same gain bandwidthcan be used. (2-2) The minimum frequency spacing is 125 GHz.The widest minimum frequency spacing should be selected within the allowable optical bandwidth so as to reduce the pump depletion effect due to FWM. As shown in Figure V.3 GHz (25 GHz × 5) is suitable for the minimum channel spacing in this case. (2-3) Channel spacing is determined according to 25 GHz × M (M = 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11) to put all channels in the optical bandwidth of 11.2 nm. An integral set which satisfies the design condition (1-2) and (1-3) is selected. There are 206 combinations that satisfy the design condition. (2-4) The maximum frequency difference between each unequally spaced frequency and the nearest 200 GHz grid frequency should be less than 75 GHz so that the unequally spaced frequencies can betuned from the nearest 200 GHz grid frequency by controlling only the temperature.
Standard: G.692
output: The design conditions include: 1) The occupied optical bandwidth should be less than that of an 8-channel WDM system with 200 GHz equal channel spacing (11.2 nm) to allow the use of optical amplifiers with the same gain bandwidth. 2) The minimum frequency spacing is 125 GHz, with the widest minimum frequency spacing selected within the allowable optical bandwidth to reduce the pump depletion effect due to FWM. A spacing of 125 GHz (25 GHz × 5) is suitable. 3) Channel spacing is determined by 25 GHz × M (M = 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11) to fit all channels within the 11.2 nm optical bandwidth. 4) The maximum frequency difference between each unequally spaced frequency and the nearest 200 GHz grid frequency should be less than 75 GHz to enable tuning from the nearest 200 GHz grid frequency by controlling only the temperature.

instruction: What is the purpose of pre-equalisation at the MPI-S interface in optical communication systems?
input:
Source: Pre-equalisation can be used at interface MPI-S to increase the amount of line amplifier gain variation and gain tilt that can be tolerated by a system while still maintaining a certain level of maximum channel power difference. This in turn ensures that amplifier designs and wavelength plans are not overly constrained.
Standard: G.692
output: Pre-equalisation at the MPI-S interface is used to increase the tolerance of a system to line amplifier gain variation and gain tilt while maintaining a certain level of maximum channel power difference. It partially compensates for amplifier gain variation and gain tilt by assigning the highest channel power at MPI-S to the channel that will undergo the least line amplifier gain and the lowest channel power to the channel that will undergo the most line amplifier gain. This approach ensures that amplifier designs and wavelength plans are not overly constrained and helps in mitigating tolerances with systematic variation.

instruction: What are the potential benefits of using bidirectional WDM systems compared to unidirectional WDM systems?
input:
Source: In general, bidirectional WDM can lead to a reduction in the number of fibres and line amplifiers required as compared to systems using unidirectional WDM. A further benefit of bidirectional WDM may be performance improvement with respect to Four-Wave Mixing (FWM), particularly when being deployed with G.653 fibres.
Standard: G.692
output: Bidirectional WDM systems can reduce the number of fibers and line amplifiers required compared to unidirectional WDM systems. They may also offer performance improvements regarding Four-Wave Mixing (FWM), especially when used with G.653 fibers.

instruction: What is the impact of extending multichannel long-haul systems to include STM-64 bit-rate?
input:
Source: With respect to market requirements, the scope of G.692 has been extended to multichannel long-haul systems with STM-64 (10 Gbit/s) bit-rate. This extension has an impact on parameters andits values in the main part of G.692, for example, on: – achievable total distances of multichannel systems for STM-64; and– dispersion accommodation technique, which may lead to additional application codes.STM-64 WDM systems on G.652 fibres require a dispersion accommodation technique for all STM-64 application codes.
Standard: G.692
output: Extending multichannel long-haul systems to include STM-64 (10 Gbit/s) bit-rate impacts several parameters and their values, including the achievable total distances of multichannel systems for STM-64 and the dispersion accommodation technique. This extension may also lead to additional application codes. Specifically, STM-64 WDM systems on G.652 fibres require a dispersion accommodation technique for all STM-64 application codes.

instruction: What are the general characteristics of Raman amplifiers and Raman amplified subsystems?
input:
Source: Generic characteristics of Raman amplifiers and Raman amplified subsystems
Standard: G.665
output: Raman amplifiers and Raman amplified subsystems are characterized by their ability to provide distributed amplification over the length of the transmission fiber, utilizing the Raman scattering effect. This effect involves the transfer of energy from a pump laser to the signal light, resulting in signal amplification. Key characteristics include wide bandwidth amplification, low noise figure, and the ability to amplify signals in both the forward and backward directions. The performance of Raman amplifiers depends on factors such as pump power, wavelength, and the fiber's Raman gain coefficient. They are particularly useful in dense wavelength division multiplexing (DWDM) systems for extending reach and improving signal quality.

instruction: What are the key parameters used to characterize Raman amplifiers?
output: Raman amplifiers are characterized by several key parameters including optical signal power parameters, gain parameters, gain spectrum parameters, noise parameters, pump power parameters, pump leakage parameters, polarization dependent parameters, channel addition/removal response, reflectance parameters, insertion loss parameters, and other miscellaneous parameters. These parameters help in defining the performance and operational characteristics of both distributed and discrete Raman amplifiers.

instruction: What are the generic characteristics specified for Raman amplifiers and Raman amplified subsystems?
input:
Source: This Recommendation identifies the definitions and test methods of performance parameters of optical fibre Raman amplifiers and Raman amplified subsystems. In the case of distributed or discrete Raman amplifiers (forward pumped, reverse pumped, bidirectionally pumped) or composite distributed Raman and discrete amplifiers, the generic characteristics of those amplifiers and subsystems are also specified.
Standard: G.665
output: The generic characteristics specified for Raman amplifiers and Raman amplified subsystems include definitions and test methods of performance parameters. These characteristics apply to various types of Raman amplifiers such as distributed or discrete Raman amplifiers (forward pumped, reverse pumped, bidirectionally pumped) and composite distributed Raman and discrete amplifiers. The specifications cover the operational and performance aspects essential for evaluating and standardizing these amplifiers and subsystems.

instruction: What is the definition of equivalent input power in the context of Raman amplifiers?
input:
Source: The power at the input reference point when the Raman pump is de-activated. For a reverse pumped Raman amplifier, the input reference point is at point RPi in Figure 1. For other Raman amplifier configurations, see 5.3.
Standard: G.665
output: Equivalent input power is defined as the power at the input reference point when the Raman pump is de-activated. For a reverse pumped Raman amplifier, the input reference point is at point RPi. For other Raman amplifier configurations, the specific input reference point may vary as detailed in the relevant sections.

instruction: What is the average slope of the multichannel net gain spectrum envelope and how is it determined?
input:
Source: For the wavelength λi and its correspondent net gain G i, it is possible to approximate G i via linear equation: a b Gi i +λ=ˆ Where a and b are chosen such that 2 0) ˆ(in iiG G−∑ = is minimized. The average slope of multichannel net gain spectrum envelope will be the b in the above linear equation.
Standard: G.665
output: The average slope of the multichannel net gain spectrum envelope is represented by the coefficient 'b' in the linear equation G_i = a + bλ_i, where G_i is the net gain at wavelength λ_i. The coefficients 'a' and 'b' are chosen to minimize the sum of squared differences between the actual net gains and the gains predicted by the linear equation across all wavelengths. This slope 'b' quantifies the rate of change of net gain with respect to wavelength across the spectrum.

instruction: What is the effective noise figure in the context of distributed amplification?
input:
Source: The effective noise figure is the noise figure of an equivalent discrete optical amplifier placed at the end of the optical fibre, which produces the effective gain and the same ASE output power as the distributed amplification. In the case of a composite amplifier, this includes the gain and ASE noise of the conventional OA.
Standard: G.665
output: The effective noise figure is defined as the noise figure of an equivalent discrete optical amplifier positioned at the end of an optical fiber. This equivalent amplifier produces the same effective gain and the same amplified spontaneous emission (ASE) output power as the distributed amplification. In composite amplifiers, this includes both the gain and ASE noise of the conventional optical amplifier.

instruction: What are the components of pump leakage in a composite amplifier?
input:
Source: In a composite amplifier, the pump leakage has the components contributed by the Raman amplifier and components contributed by the OA.
Standard: G.665
output: In a composite amplifier, the pump leakage consists of components contributed by both the Raman amplifier and the optical amplifier (OA).

instruction: What is the definition of steady-state change in channel gain due to the addition or removal of one or more other channels in a multichannel configuration?
input:
Source: Steady-state change in channel gain of any one of the channels due to the addition/removal of one or more other channels, for a given multichannel configuration.
Standard: G.665
output: The steady-state change in channel gain refers to the alteration in the gain of any one channel that occurs after the system has stabilized, following the addition or removal of one or more other channels in a given multichannel configuration. This parameter is critical for understanding how the system behaves under steady-state conditions after such changes.

instruction: What are the different classifications of devices with Raman amplification?
input:
Source: The devices with Raman amplification can be classified as follows: • forward pumped Raman amplifiers; • reverse pumped Raman amplifiers; • bidirectionally pumped Raman amplifiers; • discrete Raman amplifiers (including composite discrete Raman/erbium amplifiers); • composite forward pumped Raman and discrete amplifiers; • composite reverse pumped Raman and discrete amplifiers; • composite bidirectionally pumped Raman and discrete amplifiers. The above classification covers both the single-channel case and the multichannel case.
Standard: G.665
output: Devices with Raman amplification can be classified into several types: forward pumped Raman amplifiers, reverse pumped Raman amplifiers, bidirectionally pumped Raman amplifiers, discrete Raman amplifiers (including composite discrete Raman/erbium amplifiers), composite forward pumped Raman and discrete amplifiers, composite reverse pumped Raman and discrete amplifiers, and composite bidirectionally pumped Raman and discrete amplifiers. This classification applies to both single-channel and multichannel cases.

instruction: What is the definition of net gain in a forward pumped Raman amplifier?
input:
Source: The net gain is the on-off gain with the loss between the reference points FPi and FPo subtracted from it.
Standard: G.665
output: The net gain in a forward pumped Raman amplifier is defined as the on-off gain minus the loss between the reference points FPi (Forward Pumped signal input) and FPo (Forward Pumped signal output).

instruction: What are the characteristics of composite Raman amplifiers in terms of gain passband range for reverse pumped and bidirectionally pumped configurations?
input:
Source: Gain passband range GMP NA GMP NA
Standard: G.665
output: For reverse pumped configurations, the gain passband range is specified as GMP (Guaranteed Minimum Performance) for single channel and not applicable (NA) for multichannel. For bidirectionally pumped configurations, it is GMP for single channel and NA for multichannel.

instruction: What is the purpose of using an equivalent model of a discrete amplifier at the egress point of the fibre in distributed Raman amplifiers?
input:
Source: In order to simplify evaluation of the system performance, the distributed amplification can be considered equivalent to discrete amplification if amplification parameters are measured at the end of the transmission fibre. That arrangement will also be useful when the Raman amplifiers are compared with the traditional EDFA links.
Standard: G.665
output: The purpose of using an equivalent model of a discrete amplifier at the egress point of the fibre in distributed Raman amplifiers is to simplify the evaluation of system performance. This model produces the same effective gain and ASE output power as the distributed amplification, focusing on the signal power and noise ejected from the egress point rather than the exact power distributions along the transmission fibre. It allows for a convenient comparison with traditional EDFA links and accounts for the ASE output power being potentially lower due to the attenuation within the fibre.

instruction: How are equivalent input parameters defined for distributed Raman amplifiers when the pump laser is shut down?
input:
Source: Equivalent input parameters can be defined at the equivalent input reference point when the power of the pump laser injecting into the transmission fibre is shut down. Under this condition, the equivalent input power and input OSNR can be measured.
Standard: G.665
output: Equivalent input parameters for distributed Raman amplifiers are defined at the equivalent input reference point when the pump laser injecting into the transmission fiber is shut down. Under this condition, the equivalent input power and input OSNR can be measured.

instruction: What are the key differences between ITU-T and IEC interface definitions in optical fiber systems?
input:
Source: ITU-T defines interfaces shown in Figure III.1 as R and S. To the left of the R interface is regarded as the Transmitter/Source. The points between R and S are considered the link or span and the points to the right of Point S are considered the Receiver. The actual location of the reference point may or may not correspond to a physically accessible point. Often, it is a point inside of the fibre which must be cut to explicitly access the interface. IEC defines interfaces as always at physical points such as connectors or splice locations. These are shown in Figure III.1 as locations A, B, C, and D. Losses are defined as the loss between two interfaces. The power is measured with the link as shown, referenced to the link without the section shown. For example, to measure the loss of the connector pair and the device (shown in the gray box) between B and C, the power at the receiver would be measured with the device inserted in the link. Then the reference power would be measured at the receiver with the connector joined at points B and C as shown in Figure III.2. This results in the loss of the device and one connector pair. The existence of connectors is illustrative, and alternatively the interfaces could be splice points. Connectors (or optical splices) are always assumed to be of the same type and yield the same loss when mated or interchanged in the IEC context. In the ITU-T case, the loss would be specified between points R and S, resulting in the loss of the device and two connector pairs. The ITU-T interface is never defined as occurring in the middle of the connector. Therefore, ITU-T span losses will always differ from the IEC test method losses by the loss of one joint or connector as appropriate. In the ITU-T context, the losses of the connector or joint are defined to be explicitly the actual connector losses for connectors between the interface points. No inter-changeability of connectors is implied. The user is advised to take this difference into consideration when comparing device specifications and testing reports (IEC Publications) versus link and span designs (ITU-T Recommendations).
Standard: G.665
output: The key differences between ITU-T and IEC interface definitions in optical fiber systems are as follows: ITU-T defines interfaces R and S, where R is to the left (Transmitter/Source), S is to the right (Receiver), and the points between are the link or span. These reference points may not correspond to physically accessible points and can be inside the fiber. IEC defines interfaces at physical points like connectors or splice locations, labeled A, B, C, and D. Loss measurements differ: IEC measures loss between two interfaces with the link as shown, referenced to the link without the section, resulting in the loss of the device and one connector pair. ITU-T measures loss between points R and S, including the device and two connector pairs, making ITU-T span losses always differ by the loss of one joint or connector compared to IEC. Additionally, IEC assumes connectors or splices are of the same type with the same loss when mated, while ITU-T does not imply interchangeability of connectors.

instruction: What is the impact of double Rayleigh scatter noise in Raman amplifiers?
input:
Source: LEWIS (S.A.E.), CHERNIKOV (S.V.), TAYLOR (J.R.): Characterization of Double Rayleigh Scatter Noise in Raman Amplifiers, IEEE Photon. Technol. Lett., Vol. 12, pp. 528-530, May 2000.
Standard: G.665
output: Double Rayleigh scatter noise in Raman amplifiers can significantly degrade the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of the amplified signal. This noise is generated when the signal light undergoes multiple Rayleigh scattering events within the amplifier, leading to backward-propagating light that interferes with the forward-propagating signal. The characterization of this noise is critical for optimizing amplifier performance, as it can limit the achievable gain and the overall system performance in optical communication networks.

instruction: What are the characteristics of a bending-loss insensitive single-mode optical fibre and cable?
input:
Source: Characteristics of a bending -loss insensitive single -mode optical fibre and cable
Standard: G.657
output: A bending-loss insensitive single-mode optical fibre and cable is designed to minimize signal loss when the fibre is bent. This type of fibre typically has a reduced mode field diameter and a specially designed refractive index profile to enhance bending performance. It is particularly useful in applications where fibres are subject to tight bends, such as in dense urban environments or inside buildings. The exact specifications can vary, but these fibres generally maintain low attenuation even at bend radii as small as 5mm.

instruction: What are the two categories of single-mode fibers recommended for improved bending performance in optical networks?
input:
Source: It is the aim of Recommendation ITU -T G.657 to support this optimization by recommending strongly improved bending performance compared with the existing ITU -T G.652 single -mode fibre and cables. This is done by means of two categories of single -mode fibre s, one of which, category A, is fully compliant with the ITU -T G.652 single -mode fibres and can be deployed throughout the general transport and datacentre networks as well as the access network. The other, category B, is not necessarily compliant with Rec ommendation ITU -T G.652 but is capable of low values of macrobending losses at very low bend radii and is intended for application in the access network inside buildings or near buildings (e.g., outside building riser cabling). These category B fibres are system compatibl e with ITU -T G.657.A and ITU -T G.652.D fibres in access networks.
Standard: G.657
output: The two categories of single-mode fibers recommended for improved bending performance are category A and category B. Category A fibers are fully compliant with ITU-T G.652 single-mode fibers and can be deployed throughout general transport and datacentre networks as well as access networks. Category B fibers are not necessarily compliant with ITU-T G.652 but are capable of low values of macrobending losses at very low bend radii, intended for application in access networks inside buildings or near buildings.

instruction: What is the mode field diameter in optical fibers?
input:
Source: 6.1 Mode field diameter
Standard: G.657
output: The mode field diameter (MFD) in optical fibers refers to the diameter of the area where the light propagates in the fiber core. It is a critical parameter because it affects the fiber's ability to couple light efficiently with other fibers or devices. The MFD is typically slightly larger than the physical core diameter due to the spreading of the optical mode into the cladding. For single-mode fibers, the MFD is usually in the range of 8 to 10 micrometers at the wavelength of 1310 nm.

instruction: What are the key characteristics of single-mode fibers optimized for improved macrobending loss?
input:
Source: the specific use in an optical access network and some particular areas of general transport and datacentre networks puts different demands on the fibre and cable. Due to dense distribution and drop -cable network, limited space and the many manipulations in parts of these networks, fibr e and cable requirements may be optimized for improved macrobending loss. It is the aim of this Recommendation to support this optimization by recommending different attribute values for the existing ITU -T G.652 single -mode fibre and cables and by recommending other categories of single -mode fibre types.
Standard: G.657
output: Single-mode fibers optimized for improved macrobending loss typically feature enhanced bending performance to minimize signal loss in tight bend scenarios. These fibers are designed with specific attribute values that may include reduced mode field diameter, improved chromatic dispersion characteristics, and modified attenuation specifications. They are categorized under different types, such as G.657.A and G.657.B, each tailored for specific network applications including access networks, general transport networks, and datacentres. The optimization supports dense distribution and drop-cable networks where space is limited and frequent manipulations occur.

instruction: What are the two main categories of single-mode optical fibre cables described for improved bending loss performance?
input:
Source: This Recommendation describes two categories of single -mode optical fibre cable with improved bending loss performance compared with that of ITU -T G.652 fibres... Category A contains two subcategories which differ in macrobending loss... Category B fibres are optimized for further reduced macrobending loss and therefore are capable of being used at very low values of bending radius.
Standard: G.657
output: The two main categories are Category A and Category B. Category A fibres are optimized for reduced macrobending loss compared to G.652.D fibres and can be deployed in access networks, metro networks, and other networks requiring bending-loss insensitive fibres. They are suitable for use throughout the 1260 nm to 1625 nm range. Category A includes two subcategories: A1 for a minimum design radius of 10 mm and A2 for a minimum design radius of 7.5 mm. Category B fibres are optimized for further reduced macrobending loss, capable of being used at very low bending radii, and are intended for short reach distances, particularly inside buildings or near buildings, suitable for the same wavelength range as Category A.

instruction: What are the key characteristics of single-mode optical fibers and cables as defined in ITU-T ?
input:
Source: The optical fibre characteristics that provide the essential design framework for fibre manufacture, system design and use in outside plant networks are recommended in [ITU-T G.652]. In this clause, the emphasis is on attributes that optimize the fibre and cable in macrobending behaviour which
Standard: G.657
output: The key characteristics of single-mode optical fibers and cables include attributes that optimize performance in macrobending behavior, essential for fiber manufacture, system design, and use in outside plant networks. These characteristics are designed to ensure minimal signal loss and high performance under various environmental conditions.

instruction: What is the recommended nominal value of the cladding diameter for optical fibers?
input:
Source: The recommended nominal value of the cladding diameter is 125 m. A tolerance is also specified and shall not exceed the value in Tables 1 and 2 in clause 8. The cladding deviation from the nominal shall not exceed the specified tolerance.
Standard: G.657
output: The recommended nominal value of the cladding diameter for optical fibers is 125 μm, with a specified tolerance that should not exceed the values provided in the relevant tables.

instruction: What factors influence macrobending loss in optical fibers?
input:
Source: Macrobending loss observed in uncabled fibres varies with wavelength, bend ing radius and the number of turns about a mandrel with a specified radius. Macrobending loss shall not exceed the maximum value given in Tables 1 and 2 in clause 8 for the specified wavelength(s), bend radii and number of turns. The actual low radius exposure of the fibre is on relatively short lengths only. As the typical choice of the bending radius and the length of the bent fibre may vary depending upon the design of the fibre management system and the installation practice, a specification at one single bending radius is no longer sufficient. Although modelling results on various fibre types have been published, no generally applicable bending loss model is available to describe the loss versus bend ing radius behaviour. For this reason, the recommended maximum macrobending loss is specified at different bend radii in Tables 1 and 2 in clause 8. While a baseline on macrobending performance can be established for uncabled fibres, the actual design and materials of cable construction can contribute to the resulting performance in the field. Macrobending loss in cabled fibre may differ from that obse rved in uncabled fibre measurements because of the bend -limiting effect of the cable structure on the fibre bend. The study into the macrobending effects of cabling is ongoing, which may result in the need for any additional cable specifications or paramet ers in the future. Macrobending loss of installed cabled fibres in in -building networks may depend on the installation technique used. According to [ITU -T L.103], any fibre bend ing radius remaining after cable installation is recommended to be large enough to limit the macrobending loss and long -term strain that would reduce the lifetime of the fibre. For that purpose, certain demanding installation techniques are not recommended (e .g., stapling indoor cable using flat staples). As optical bending losses increase with wavelength, a loss specification at the highest envisioned wavelength, i.e., either 1550 nm or 1625 nm, suffices. If required, a customer and supplier can agree on a lower or higher specification wavelength. NOTE 4 – In general, the macrobending loss is influenced by the choice of the values for other fibre attributes, such as the mode field diameter, chromatic dispersion coefficient and the fibre cut -off wavelength. Optimization with respect to macrobending l osses usually involves a trade -off between the values of these fibre attributes.
Standard: G.657
output: Macrobending loss in optical fibers is influenced by several factors including wavelength, bending radius, the number of turns about a mandrel with a specified radius, and the deployment conditions such as piece length and specific bending scenarios. The loss increases with wavelength, making specifications at the highest envisioned wavelength (1550 nm or 1625 nm) sufficient. Additionally, the design and materials of cable construction, as well as the installation technique, can affect the macrobending loss in cabled fibers. The actual performance may differ between uncabled and cabled fibers due to the bend-limiting effect of the cable structure. Optimization of macrobending losses often involves trade-offs with other fiber attributes like mode field diameter, chromatic dispersion coefficient, and fiber cut-off wavelength.

instruction: What considerations are important when fusion splicing fibers of different substances?
input:
Source: Care may be needed in fusion splicing fibres of different substances. Provisional results indicate that adequate splice loss and strength can be achieved when splicing different high -silica fibres.
Standard: G.657
output: When fusion splicing fibers of different substances, care must be taken to ensure adequate splice loss and strength. Provisional results indicate that acceptable splice loss and strength can be achieved when splicing different high-silica fibers.

instruction: What is the range for the chromatic dispersion coefficient D(λ) from 1460 nm to 1625 nm?
input:
Source: From 1460 nm to 1625 nm, chromatic dispersion coefficient D(λ) at wavelength λ is bound by the following inequality: 8.625 +0.052(λ−1460 )≤𝐷(𝜆)≤12.472 + 0.068 (λ−1460 ) (6-2)
Standard: G.657
output: The chromatic dispersion coefficient D(λ) at wavelength λ from 1460 nm to 1625 nm is bound by the inequality: 8.625 + 0.052(λ−1460) ≤ D(λ) ≤ 12.472 + 0.068(λ−1460).

instruction: What is the purpose of the PMD link design value, PMD Q, supplied by the manufacturer?
input:
Source: The manufacturer shall supply a PMD link design value, PMD Q, that serves as a statistical upper bound for the PMD coefficient of the concatenated optical fibre cables within a defined possible link of M cable sections. The upper bound is defined in terms of a small probability level, Q, which is the probability that a concatenated PMD coefficient value exceeds PMD Q. For the values of M and Q given in Tables 1 and 2 in clause 8, the value of PMD Q shall not exceed the maximum PMD coefficient specified in Tables 1 and 2 in clause 8.
Standard: G.657
output: The PMD link design value, PMD Q, serves as a statistical upper bound for the PMD coefficient of concatenated optical fibre cables within a defined possible link of M cable sections. It is defined in terms of a small probability level, Q, representing the probability that a concatenated PMD coefficient value exceeds PMD Q. This value ensures that the PMD coefficient does not exceed specified maximums for given values of M and Q.

instruction: What is the range of nominal values for the core diameter in ITU-T A fibers?
input:
Source: Range of nominal values  8.6-9.2 µm
Standard: G.657

instruction: What method can be used to evaluate the macrobending loss of optical fibers?

instruction: What factors influence the lifetime expectation of single-mode fiber under small radius bending?
input:
Source: Lifetime expectation in the case of small radius bending of single-mode fibre
Standard: G.657
output: The lifetime expectation of single-mode fiber under small radius bending is influenced by several factors including the bending radius, the mechanical properties of the fiber, environmental conditions such as temperature and humidity, and the presence of any protective coatings or materials. Smaller bending radii can induce higher stresses on the fiber, potentially leading to microcracks and reduced lifetime. The fiber's design, such as its mode field diameter and cladding diameter, also plays a critical role in its resistance to bending-induced losses and damage.

instruction: What are the key components and subsystems tested in optical network parameter methods?
output: The key components and subsystems tested in optical network parameter methods include Optical Add/Drop Multiplexer (OADM) subsystems for WDM, Asymmetric branching components (wavelength non-selective), Optical attenuators, Optical branching components (wavelength non-selective and for PONs), Optical connectors, Delay line interferometers, Dynamic channel equalizers (DCE), Optical filters, Optical isolators, Passive (chromatic) dispersion compensators, Single optical channel passive (chromatic) dispersion compensators, Optical splices, Optical switches, Optical terminations, Tuneable (chromatic) dispersion compensators, Tuneable filters, and Optical wavelength MUX/DMUX.

instruction: What are the key specifications for fibre optic passive power control devices?
input:
Source: IEC 60869 -1:2018 , Fibre optic interconnecting devices and passive components  – Fibre optic passive power control devices  – Part 1: Generic specification .
Standard: G.671
output: Fibre optic passive power control devices are specified to manage optical power levels within fibre optic systems. Key specifications include the ability to control power without wavelength selectivity, ensuring stability and reliability across various operating conditions. These devices must comply with generic specifications that cover performance criteria, environmental conditions, and mechanical durability.

instruction: What is the function of an optical add/drop multiplexer (OADM) subsystem in WDM transmission systems?
input:
Source: 3.2.1.1 optical add/drop multiplexer (OADM) subsystem : A wavelength selective branching device (used in WDM transmission systems) having a wavelength 'drop' function in which one or more optical signals can be transferred from an input port to either an output port or drop port(s) depending on the wavelength of the signal and also having a wavelength 'add' function in which optical signals presented to the add port(s) are also transferred to the output port as shown in Figure 1.
Standard: G.671
output: An optical add/drop multiplexer (OADM) subsystem in WDM transmission systems performs wavelength selective branching. It has a 'drop' function where one or more optical signals can be transferred from an input port to either an output port or drop port(s) based on the signal's wavelength. Additionally, it features an 'add' function where optical signals presented to the add port(s) are transferred to the output port.

instruction: What is an asymmetric branching component in optical communication systems?
input:
Source: asymmetric bran ching component : A passive component (wavelength non -selective) possessing three or more ports which shares optical power among its ports in a predetermined fashion, without any amplification, switching or other active modulation (clause  1.1 in [IEC  60875 -1]). A tap coupler is used as a synonym for an asymmetric branching device. The majority of the optical power is normally transferred to the main port of a tap coupler while a small fraction (1% to 20%) is transferred to the tap port. The ratio of the opti cal power in the main port to the tap port as a percentage is called the coupling fraction F. Optical branching devices can be divided into categories of symmetric and asymmetric. A device whose transfer matrix is diagonally asymmetric, i.e., where for all  i and o, tio and toi are nominally unequal (clause 1.3.19 in [IEC 60875 -1]).
Standard: G.671
output: An asymmetric branching component is a passive, wavelength non-selective device with three or more ports that distributes optical power among its ports in a predetermined manner without amplification, switching, or active modulation. It typically transfers the majority of the optical power to the main port, with a small fraction (1% to 20%) directed to the tap port. The coupling fraction F describes the ratio of optical power in the main port to the tap port as a percentage. This device's transfer matrix is diagonally asymmetric, meaning the power transfer between any two ports is nominally unequal in both directions.

instruction: What is the purpose of a passive chromatic dispersion compensator in optical communication systems?
input:
Source: passive ( chromatic) dispersion compensator : A passive component used to compensate the chromatic dispersion of an optical path.
Standard: G.671
output: A passive chromatic dispersion compensator is used to correct the chromatic dispersion in an optical path, ensuring signal integrity over long distances by compensating for the wavelength-dependent speed variations of light in optical fibers.

instruction: What is the definition of 1 dB passband width for an optical filter?
input:
Source: The 1 dB passband width is symmetrical with respect to the nominal centre frequency fc of the filter, i.e., the loss is required to be within 1 dB of the minimum at all frequencies between fc – D1/2 and fc + D1/2.
Standard: G.671
output: The 1 dB passband width of an optical filter is the total frequency range over which the filter's loss is within 1 dB of the minimum loss within that range. It is symmetrical with respect to the nominal centre frequency fc of the filter, meaning the loss is required to be within 1 dB of the minimum at all frequencies between fc – D1/2 and fc + D1/2.

instruction: What is the definition of attenuation accuracy for optical attenuators?
input:
Source: The difference between nominal and actual insertion loss of the attenuator.
Standard: G.671
output: Attenuation accuracy for optical attenuators refers to the difference between the nominal and actual insertion loss of the attenuator.

instruction: What is channel attenuation resolution in the context of dynamic channel equalizers?
input:
Source: The channel attenuation resolution is the maximum difference between the insertion losses within a channel frequency (or wavelength) range of any two adjacent attenuation settings within the dynamic attenuation range of a dynamic channel equalizer (in dB).
Standard: G.671
output: Channel attenuation resolution refers to the maximum difference in insertion losses (measured in dB) between any two adjacent attenuation settings within the dynamic attenuation range of a dynamic channel equalizer, specifically within a channel's frequency or wavelength range.

instruction: What is the definition of channel frequency range in DWDM devices?
input:
Source: The frequency range within which a DWDM device is required to operate with a specified performance. For a particular nominal channel central frequency, fnomi, this frequency range is from fimin = (fnomi – Δfmax) to fimax = (fnomi + fmax), where fmax is the maximum channel central frequency deviation or the spectral excursion.
Standard: G.671
output: The channel frequency range in DWDM devices is the frequency range within which the device is required to operate with specified performance. For a given nominal channel central frequency (fnomi), this range extends from fimin = (fnomi – Δfmax) to fimax = (fnomi + Δfmax), where Δfmax is the maximum channel central frequency deviation or spectral excursion.

instruction: What is channel non-uniformity in WDM devices?
input:
Source: 3.2.2.13  channel non -uniformity : The difference (in dB) between the powers of the channel with the most power (in dB m) and the channel with the least power (in dBm). This applies to a multichannel signal across the operating wavelength range.
Standard: G.671
output: Channel non-uniformity in WDM devices refers to the difference in power levels, measured in dB, between the channel with the highest power and the channel with the lowest power across the operating wavelength range of a multichannel signal.

instruction: What is the channel wavelength range for a CWDM or WWDM device?
input:
Source: The wavelength range within which a CWDM or WWDM device is required to operate with a specified performance. For a particular nominal channel central wavelength, nomi, this wavelength range is from imin = (nomi – max) to imax = (nomi + max), where max is the maximum channel wavelength deviation.
Standard: G.671
output: The channel wavelength range for a CWDM or WWDM device is defined from λimin = (λnomi – Δλmax) to λimax = (λnomi + Δλmax), where λnomi is the nominal channel central wavelength and Δλmax is the maximum channel wavelength deviation. This range specifies the wavelengths within which the device must operate with specified performance.

instruction: What is incremental attenuation in the context of variable attenuators?
input:
Source: A term applicable only to variable attenuators. It refers to the difference between the nominal attenuation of the component at a given setting and the minimum nominal attenuation (clause 1.3.6 in [IEC  60869 -1]).
Standard: G.671
output: Incremental attenuation refers to the difference between the nominal attenuation of a variable attenuator at a specific setting and its minimum nominal attenuation. This term is exclusively applicable to variable attenuators and quantifies the additional attenuation introduced by adjusting the attenuator from its minimum setting.

instruction: What is the definition of operating wavelength range for a passive optical component?
input:
Source: 3.2.2.3 1 operating wavelength range : The specified range of wavelengths from imin to imax about a nominal operating wavelength i, within which a passive component is designed to operate with a specified pe rformance (clause 1.3.21 in [IEC  60875 -1]). NOTE 1 – For an optical branching component with more than one operating wavelength, the corresponding wavelength ranges are not necessarily equal (clause 1.3.21 in [IEC  60875 -1]). NOTE 2 – The components, includ ing attenuators, terminations, connectors and splices may operate with a specified performance or acceptable performance even outside the specified range of wavelengths.
Standard: G.671
output: The operating wavelength range for a passive optical component is defined as the specified range of wavelengths from λimin to λimax about a nominal operating wavelength λi, within which the component is designed to operate with a specified performance. This range may vary for optical branching components with more than one operating wavelength, and certain components like attenuators, terminations, connectors, and splices may still operate acceptably outside this specified range.

instruction: What is polarization dependent frequency shift in the context of delay line interferometers?
input:
Source: The maximum frequency shift (GHz) of the transmitted optical intensity maxima or minima of a delay line interferometer among all polarization states.
Standard: G.671
output: Polarization dependent frequency shift refers to the maximum frequency shift (measured in GHz) of the transmitted optical intensity maxima or minima of a delay line interferometer across all polarization states.

instruction: What is the definition of reflectance in optical components?
input:
Source: 3.2.2.38 reflectance : The ratio of reflected power Pr to incident power Pi at a given port of a passive component, for given conditions of spectral composition, polarization and geometrical distribution. Generally expressed in dB as: R = 10 log10(Pr/Pi).
Standard: G.671
output: Reflectance in optical components is defined as the ratio of reflected power (Pr) to incident power (Pi) at a given port of a passive component, under specific conditions of spectral composition, polarization, and geometrical distribution. It is generally expressed in decibels (dB) using the formula: R = 10 log10(Pr/Pi). For different types of optical components, such as WDM devices, optical switches, and optical filters, reflectance is specified in various ways, including maximum values within operating wavelength ranges or as elements of a logarithmic transfer matrix. Notably, reflectance values exclude contributions from connectors or unterminated optical ports, which are considered separately.

instruction: What is the definition of switching time for an optical switch?
input:
Source: 3.2.2.4 3 switching time: The elapsed time it takes the switch to turn path io on or off from a particular initial state, measured from the time the actuation energy is applied or removed (clause  1.3.19 in [IEC  60876 -1]).
Standard: G.671
output: Switching time for an optical switch is defined as the elapsed time it takes the switch to turn a path on or off from a particular initial state. This time is measured from the moment the actuation energy is applied or removed.

instruction: What is unidirectional (far-end) isolation in a WDM device and how is it calculated?
input:
Source: In a WDM device able to separate k wavelengths (λ1, λ2, ..., λk) radiation coming from one input port into k output ports, each one nominally passing radiation at one specific wavelength only. The unidirectional (far-end) isolation is a measure of the part of the optical power at each wavelength exiting from the port at wavelengths different from the nominal wavelength relative to the power at the nominal wavelength. It is given by the following formula: IU = aiox – aioc. The terms aiox and aioc are elements of the logarithmic transfer matrix, where i is the input port number, o is the output port number, c is the (channel) wavelength number associated with port o and x is the isolation wavelength number, where x is any wavelength number not equal to c.
Standard: G.671
output: Unidirectional (far-end) isolation in a WDM device measures the portion of optical power at each wavelength exiting from a port at wavelengths different from the nominal wavelength, relative to the power at the nominal wavelength. It is calculated using the formula IU = aiox – aioc, where aiox and aioc are elements of the logarithmic transfer matrix. Here, i is the input port number, o is the output port number, c is the channel wavelength number associated with port o, and x is any isolation wavelength number not equal to c. This measurement helps in assessing the device's ability to separate different wavelengths effectively.

instruction: What is the definition of uniformity in optical components?
input:
Source: 3.2.2.4 8 uniformity : The logarithmic transfer matrix of a component may contain a specified set of coefficients that are nominally finite and equal. In this case, the range of these coefficients aio, expressed in decibels, is termed the uniformity of the component (clause 1.3.16 in [IEC 60875-1]). 3.2.2.4 9 uniformity (delay line interferometer only) : The uniformity of the delay line interferometer is the difference between the insertion loss from input to one output at a transmission peak wavelength and the insertion loss from input to the other output at its transmission peak wavelength closest to the first output's transmission peak wavelength.
Standard: G.671
output: Uniformity in optical components refers to the range of nominally finite and equal coefficients in the logarithmic transfer matrix of a component, expressed in decibels. For delay line interferometers specifically, it is defined as the difference between the insertion loss from input to one output at a transmission peak wavelength and the insertion loss from input to the other output at its closest transmission peak wavelength.

instruction: How is the optical power reduction calculated in decibels for a logarithmic transfer matrix coefficient in optical branching and WDM devices?
input:
Source: asrw = –10 log tsrw where tsrw is the transfer matrix coefficient, s is the port number into which optical power is sent to the device for measurement, r is the port number used to measure the return and w the wavelength number of the measurement (i.e., the measurement is performed at wavelength w).
Standard: G.671
output: The optical power reduction in decibels (asrw) for a logarithmic transfer matrix coefficient in optical branching and WDM devices is calculated using the formula: asrw = –10 log(tsrw), where tsrw is the transfer matrix coefficient. This represents the optical power reduction out of port number r when unit power is sent into port number s at wavelength number w.

instruction: What is the definition of a port in the context of optical components?
input:

output: A port in the context of optical components is defined as an optical fibre or an optical fibre connector attached to an optical component for the entry and/or exit of the optical power.

instruction: What is the purpose of the transfer matrix in defining the optical properties of an optical switch?
input:
Source: The optical properties of an optical switch can be defined in an n  n matrix of coefficients ( n is the total number of ports). The T matrix represents the on -state paths (worst -case transmission), and the To matrix represents the off -state paths (worst -case isolation). In general, the transfer matrices are shown in Figure 17. This matrix is intended for definition purposes only (clause 1.3.6 in [IEC  60876 -1]).
Standard: G.671
output: The transfer matrix is used to define the optical properties of an optical switch by representing the on-state paths with the T matrix, which indicates worst-case transmission, and the off-state paths with the To matrix, which indicates worst-case isolation. This n x n matrix, where n is the total number of ports, is intended for definition purposes to characterize the switch's performance in terms of transmission and isolation for each port connection.

instruction: What are the primary functions of optical monitoring in DWDM systems?
input:
Source: configuration management for system and channel activation, addition of new channels, etc.; fault management to detect and to isolate faults; degradation management in order to keep the system running and to detect degradations before a fault occurs.
Standard: G.697
output: Optical monitoring in DWDM systems primarily performs three key functions: configuration management for system and channel activation, including the addition of new channels; fault management to detect and isolate faults; and degradation management to maintain system operation and detect degradations before they lead to faults.

instruction: What are the components of parameter encoding in optical communication systems?
output: Parameter encoding in optical communication systems typically includes several components: Wavelength ID, which is a 32-bit field used to identify specific wavelengths; Parameter ID source, an 8-bit field indicating the source of the parameter; Parameter ID, another 8-bit field that specifies the parameter being referenced; and Value of parameters, a 32-bit field that contains the actual value of the specified parameter.

instruction: What are the key objectives of optical monitoring in DWDM systems?
input:
Source: The purpose of this Recommendation is to indicate a minimum, but not exhaustive, set of optical parameters that can be used to perform optical monitoring (OM) functions in dense wavelength division multiplexing (DWDM) systems and optical network elements [ONEs, e.g., reconfigurable optical add-drop multiplexers (ROADMs) ], particularly relevant to those network elements without optical-electrical-optical conversions. In order to achieve this objective, this Recommendation: 1) indicates methods for measuring the optical signal degradation; 2) classifies those methods by type; 3) defines suitable optical parameters to detect optical signal degradation; and 4) describes the applications or conditions where these optical parameters can be relevant.
Standard: G.697
output: The key objectives of optical monitoring in DWDM systems include indicating a minimum set of optical parameters for monitoring functions, measuring optical signal degradation, classifying measurement methods by type, defining suitable optical parameters to detect degradation, and describing applications or conditions where these parameters are relevant. This applies particularly to network elements without optical-electrical-optical conversions.

instruction: What is stimulated Brillouin scattering (SBS) in optical fibers?
input:
Source: – stimulated Brillouin scattering (SBS)
Standard: G.697
output: Stimulated Brillouin scattering (SBS) is a nonlinear optical effect that occurs in optical fibers where light interacts with acoustic phonons, leading to the generation of backward-propagating Stokes waves. This phenomenon can cause signal degradation and power loss in optical communication systems.

instruction: What does the acronym 3R stand for in optical communication systems?
input:
Source: 3R  Re-amplification, Reshaping and Retiming
Standard: G.697
output: In optical communication systems, 3R stands for Re-amplification, Reshaping, and Retiming. These are key processes used in signal regeneration to improve signal quality over long distances.

instruction: What are the key parameters monitored in synchronous digital hierarchy (SDH) networks for management purposes?
input:
Source: The management of existing synchronous digital hierarchy ( SDH ) networks relies on monitoring digital parameters such as bit error ratio (BER), errored second ratio (ESR) and severely errored second ratio (SESR), which are measured at the electrical layer (at 3R regenerators), as described in [b-ITU-T G.826].
Standard: G.697
output: The key parameters monitored in SDH networks for management purposes include bit error ratio (BER), errored second ratio (ESR), and severely errored second ratio (SESR). These parameters are measured at the electrical layer, specifically at 3R regenerators, to assess the performance and reliability of the network.

instruction: What are the two different forms of signal monitoring described in optical network management?
input:
Source: Clauses 6.1 to 6.6 describe two different forms of signal monitoring, namely time domain and frequency domain methods, and explain the differences between signal monitoring and equipment monitoring, as well as the differences between embedded and external monitoring devices.
Standard: G.697
output: The two different forms of signal monitoring in optical network management are time domain and frequency domain methods. Time domain methods analyze the behavior of the optical signal in the time domain, being sensitive to both noise and distortion effects, and are closer to full BER (Bit Error Rate) measurements. Frequency domain methods, on the other hand, focus on analyzing the signal's frequency components.

instruction: What are the limitations of using sampling oscilloscopes and Q-factor meters for signals with advanced modulation formats at 40 Gbit/s or 100 Gbit/s?
input:
Source: NOTE – The above description of sampling oscilloscopes and Q-factor metre s is for up to 10 Gbit/s NRZ or RZ signals. Sampling oscilloscope and Q-factor measurements may not provide useful results for 40 Gbit/s or 100 Gbit/s signals with advanced modulation formats.
Standard: G.697
output: Sampling oscilloscopes and Q-factor meters are effective for analyzing signals up to 10 Gbit/s with NRZ or RZ modulation formats. However, for signals at 40 Gbit/s or 100 Gbit/s with advanced modulation formats, these tools may not provide useful results due to the complexity and higher data rates of these signals, which exceed the capabilities of traditional measurement techniques.

instruction: What are the key differences between embedded monitoring equipment and external monitoring equipment in optical networks?
input:
Source: Different monitoring points placed in the same network element can share the EME. Embedded monitoring equipment accuracy is sufficiently high to provide meaningful input for automated management decisions, achieved with relatively low effort compared to a general purpose test instrument. External monitoring equipment typically serves a different purpose than EME, used to measure additional, more sophisticated performance parameters or when a more accurate value of certain performance parameters is required. External monitoring equipment generally has higher accuracy and a wider measurement range than embedded monitoring devices.
Standard: G.697
output: Embedded monitoring equipment (EME) is integrated within network elements and is designed for continuous monitoring with relatively low effort, focusing on deviations from known nominal values within a narrow operating range. It is suitable for automated management decisions. External monitoring equipment, on the other hand, is used on-demand for more sophisticated performance parameters or higher accuracy requirements, especially for hard-to-find failures, function tests, and accurate measurements during installation, commissioning, or repair. It typically offers higher accuracy and a wider measurement range than EME, as it must provide reliable absolute measurements over the full operating range of an optical transmission system.

Standard: G.697
output: Common optical impairments in up to 10 Gbit/s systems include attenuation, optical channel power changes due to gain variations, frequency or wavelength deviation from nominal, polarization mode dispersion (PMD) of first and higher orders, four-wave mixing (FWM), amplified spontaneous emission (ASE) noise in optical amplification, chromatic dispersion, chromatic dispersion slope, reflections, laser noise, inter-channel crosstalk, interferometric crosstalk, cross-phase modulation (XPM), self-phase modulation (SPM), stimulated Brillouin scattering (SBS), and stimulated Raman scattering (SRS). The relative frequency of occurrence varies from high for attenuation and optical channel power changes, to medium for PMD, FWM, ASE noise, chromatic dispersion, chromatic dispersion slope, reflections, laser noise, inter-channel crosstalk, and interferometric crosstalk, and low for XPM, SPM, SBS, and SRS.

instruction: What are the typical optical impairments in 40 Gbit/s and 100 Gbit/s coherent systems using advanced modulation formats?
input:
Source: Table 2 – Optical impairments in 40 Gbit/s and 100 Gbit/s coherent systems using advanced modulation formats
Standard: G.697
output: The typical optical impairments in 40 Gbit/s and 100 Gbit/s coherent systems using advanced modulation formats include amplified spontaneous emission (ASE) noise in optical amplification, chromatic dispersion, chromatic dispersion slope, reflections, laser noise, inter-channel crosstalk, interferometric crosstalk, cross-phase modulation (XPM), self-phase modulation (SPM), cross-polarization modulation (XPolM), stimulated Brillouin scattering (SBS), and stimulated Raman scattering (SRS). These impairments can cause severe degradation of an optical signal, potentially making it undetectable by the receiver with a reasonable error ratio.

instruction: What are the key parameters monitored in optical networks to assess performance?
input:
Source: OSNR when no significant noise shaping is present; channel wavelength; Q-factor.
Standard: G.697
output: The key parameters monitored in optical networks to assess performance include Optical Signal-to-Noise Ratio (OSNR), channel wavelength, and Q-factor. These parameters help in evaluating the quality and integrity of the optical signal transmitted through the network.

instruction: What are the potential applications of Optical Monitoring (OM) in DWDM systems?
input:
Source: In DWDM systems, OM could help in the following activities: i) configuration management for system and channel activation, addition of new channels, etc.; ii) fault management to detect and to isolate faults; iii) degradation management in order to keep the system running and to detect degradations before a fault occurs.
Standard: G.697
output: Optical Monitoring (OM) in DWDM systems can be utilized for configuration management, including system and channel activation and the addition of new channels. It also plays a crucial role in fault management by detecting and isolating faults. Additionally, OM aids in degradation management to maintain system operation and identify degradations before they lead to faults.

instruction: What is the typical relationship between optical impairment penalty and occurrence rate in optical networks?
input:
Source: The optical impairments listed in Table 1 and Table 2 are all capable of causing severe degradation of an optical signal to the point of failure of the receiver to be able to detect the data with a reasonable error ratio. For any of the impairments, it is possible to plot a curve of penalty versus occurrence rate (the probability of occurrence per time). An example curve in the case of attenuation might take the form of the curve in Figure I.1. The shape of the curve and the probability levels will, of course, be different for each of the impairments on the list. On the curve for attenuation, small impairments of the order of 0.1 dB being very probable and large impairments (for example, 6 dB or greater) being very much less probable. The curve for a different impairment will have a different shape. For example, SBS might look like the curve in Figure I.2.
Standard: G.697
output: The relationship between optical impairment penalty and occurrence rate typically follows a curve where small penalties (e.g., 0.1 dB) occur with high probability, while larger penalties (e.g., 6 dB or greater) occur with much lower probability. For example, attenuation impairments show this trend, with the exact shape of the curve varying depending on the specific impairment. Stimulated Brillouin Scattering (SBS) might exhibit a curve where the occurrence rate is very low but the penalty can be very severe.

instruction: What are the typical accuracy and repeatability values for channel power measurement at the DWDM receiver input using embedded optical monitoring?
input:
Source: Channel power  2 dB (Note 1)  0.5 dB  Receiver operating range (Note 2)
Standard: G.697
output: The typical accuracy for channel power measurement at the DWDM receiver input using embedded optical monitoring is ±2 dB, with a repeatability of ±0.5 dB. The measurement range is the receiver operating range, which is the input power range over which the receiver would normally be expected to operate.

instruction: What are the accuracy and repeatability specifications for channel power measurement in embedded optical monitoring systems?
input:
Source: Channel power  ±1 dB (Note 1)  ±0.5 dB  (–40 to –10) + tap loss dBm (Note 2)
Standard: G.697

The repeatability for channel power measurement is ±0.5 dB. The measurement range for channel power is (–40 to –10) dBm plus the tap loss, where the tap loss varies depending on the monitoring tap's splitting fraction.

instruction: What is the impact of demux/mux filtering on noise levels in an OADM system?
input:
Source: Figure III.4 shows the spectrum after the mux of the OADM and a booster amplifier. Here, the situation is radically different. The noise between the channels has been strongly shaped by the combined filtering function of the demux/mux . As can be seen by the noise peak at the wavelength of the missi ng channel in this example, there is about 15 dB more noise at the channel wavelengths than at the mid -points between channels and, hence, the OSNR estimate at this point is about 15 dB optimistic. For the wavelength that has been added, however, we have t he reverse situation and the noise level at the mid -points is much higher than the noise added at the channel wavelength. The OSNR estimate for this channel is, therefore, seriously pessimistic.
Standard: G.697
output: The demux/mux filtering in an OADM system significantly shapes the noise between channels. It creates a noise peak at the wavelength of a missing channel, with approximately 15 dB more noise at the channel wavelengths compared to the mid-points between channels. This results in an OSNR estimate that is about 15 dB optimistic for existing channels. Conversely, for a newly added channel, the noise level at the mid-points is much higher than at the channel wavelength, leading to a seriously pessimistic OSNR estimate for this channel.

instruction: What are the key considerations when measuring OSNR with a narrow-band optical spectrum analyser in systems where the signal does not occupy the full channel bandwidth?
input:
Source: For a realistic OSNR measurement in the presence of noise shaping, it is essential to measure the filtered noise value in the passband of the optical filters in a system (often called "in-band" OSNR measurement). Three methods of achieving this are described in clauses III.1.1 to III.1.4. III.1.1 Narrow-band optical spectrum analyser method If the signal spectrum does not occupy the full channel bandwidth and the optical filter shape has a flat region, the OSNR can be measured with a narrow-band optical spectrum analyser (OSA). An example of this is shown in Figure III.5 for the case of a 10 Gbit/s signal in a 100 GHz channel spacing system. Here, the OSNR can be estimated by measuring the signal power and the noise in the flat region away from the signal. Care must be taken to measure the signal with a sufficiently large resolution bandwidth to capture all of the signal power, while measuring the noise with a small enough resolution bandwidth to exclude the signal. This may require a different resolution bandwidth for each part of the measurement and for the noise power to be scaled from the measurement bandwidth to the usual reference value of 0.1 nm.
Standard: G.697
output: When measuring OSNR with a narrow-band optical spectrum analyser (OSA) in systems where the signal does not occupy the full channel bandwidth, key considerations include ensuring the optical filter shape has a flat region for accurate noise measurement. The signal power must be measured with a sufficiently large resolution bandwidth to capture all signal power, while the noise should be measured with a small enough resolution bandwidth to exclude the signal. This often requires different resolution bandwidths for each part of the measurement. Additionally, the noise power needs to be scaled from the measurement bandwidth to the standard reference value of 0.1 nm for accurate OSNR estimation.

instruction: What are the key components required for the polarization extinction method of OSNR measurement?
input:
Source: An alternative method of separating the signal from the noise is to exploit the fact that, to a first approximation, the optical transmission signal is polarized, whereas the ASE noise is unpolarized. In its simplest form, a combination of a variable polarization controller and a polarization splitter/filter is used to separate the polarized signal from the unpolarized noise as shown in Figure III.7.
Standard: G.697
output: The polarization extinction method requires a variable polarization controller and a polarization beam splitter/filter. The polarization controller adjusts the polarization state of the input signal, while the polarization beam splitter separates the polarized signal from the unpolarized ASE noise. This setup allows for the measurement of the signal in one branch and the noise in the other, facilitating OSNR calculation.

instruction: What are the four problems associated with the polarization-based OSNR measurement method?
input:
Source: Four problems with this measurement method are: 
– if the polarization state of the signal at the measurement point evolves rapidly (this is likely 
to be a particular problem with aerial fibre) or the signal becomes de -polarized, then it is very 
difficult to obtain a good extinction of the si gnal; 
– if there is crosstalk between the channels, the crosstalk may or may not be included in the 
noise measurement depending on the relative polarizations of the signal and the crosstalk ; 
– polarization -dependent loss (PDL) can lead to significant measurement error due to the noise 
with the same polarization as the signal having a different amplitude to the noise with the 
orthogonal polarization ; 
– for a polarization multiplexed signal, there is a separate signal on each of the two orthogonal 
polari zations , so it is not possible to extinguish the signal using a polarization beam splitter. 
Hence, it is not possible to use this method of OSNR measurement for these signals.
Standard: G.697
output: The four problems are: 1) Rapid evolution or depolarization of the signal's polarization state at the measurement point, particularly problematic with aerial fiber, makes achieving good signal extinction difficult. 2) Crosstalk between channels may or may not be included in the noise measurement, depending on the relative polarizations of the signal and crosstalk. 3) Polarization-dependent loss (PDL) can introduce significant measurement errors because noise with the same polarization as the signal may have a different amplitude than noise with orthogonal polarization. 4) For polarization multiplexed signals, which have separate signals on each of two orthogonal polarizations, it's impossible to extinguish the signal using a polarization beam splitter, rendering this OSNR measurement method inapplicable.

instruction: What is the Q-factor in optical communication systems and how is it measured?
input:
Source: A Q-factor is measured in the time domain by analysing the statistics of the pulse shape of the optical signal. Full details can be found in [ITU -T O.201]. A Q-factor is a comprehensive measure for the signal quality of an optical channel taking into account the effects of noise, filtering and linear/non-linear distortions on the pulse shape, which is not possible with simple optical parameters alone. Under ideal conditions (only additive Gaussian noise, no linear or non-linear distortions, etc.), the BER of a binary optical channel should be the same as that indicated by a Q-factor measurement. However, these idealized conditions are rarely present in real systems and the correlation between the Q-factor of an optical signal and the BER measured after regeneration is influenced by the different receiver characteristics (noise bandwidth, impulse response, etc.) in the regenerator compared to that of the Q-factor meter. NOTE – The above description of Q-factor measurement is for up to 10 Gbit/s NRZ or RZ signals. Q-factor measurement may not apply to 40 Gbit/s or 100 Gbit/s signals with advanced modulation formats and this is for further study.
Standard: G.697
output: The Q-factor is a comprehensive measure of the signal quality of an optical channel, accounting for the effects of noise, filtering, and linear/non-linear distortions on the pulse shape. It is measured in the time domain by analyzing the statistics of the pulse shape of the optical signal. Under ideal conditions, such as only additive Gaussian noise with no linear or non-linear distortions, the bit error rate (BER) of a binary optical channel should match that indicated by a Q-factor measurement. However, real systems rarely meet these idealized conditions, and the correlation between the Q-factor and BER measured after regeneration is affected by different receiver characteristics in the regenerator compared to the Q-factor meter. Note that Q-factor measurement is applicable to up to 10 Gbit/s NRZ or RZ signals and may not apply to 40 Gbit/s or 100 Gbit/s signals with advanced modulation formats.

instruction: What is the impact of residual dispersion differences on Q-factor measurements in optical communication systems?
input:
Source: Rec. ITU-T G.697 (11/2016)  23 Figure III. 10 shows the residual dispersion versus distance for a system where the dispersion of ea ch nominally 80  km span is compensated by an 80 km DCM embedded in each line amplifier, and an additional DCM within the receiving preamplifier. In this case, for example, the Q-factor measured at point C (the input to the third line amplifier) is quite di fferent to the Q-factor at point D (the output of the same amplifier) due to the large difference in residual dispersion of the two points.
Standard: G.697
output: Residual dispersion differences in optical communication systems can significantly impact Q-factor measurements. For instance, when measuring at different points along the transmission path, such as the input and output of the same amplifier, the Q-factor can vary due to the large difference in residual dispersion at these points. This variation necessitates careful selection of measurement points, typically at amplifier outputs, to ensure accurate Q-factor assessment. Additionally, in systems covering a wide wavelength range, the mismatch between the slope of the fiber dispersion with wavelength and the inverse slope of the DCM dispersion with wavelength leads to different residual dispersion maps across channel wavelengths, further complicating Q-factor measurements.

instruction: What factors influence the choice of monitoring equipment positions in a DWDM system?
input:
Source: The choice of which option to deploy depends upon the specific characteristics of the ONE , in particular for a DWDM system , whose characteristics include length, number of spans, number of channels and inaccessibility of the sites , as well as cost/benefit considerations. Particular consideration is required because, as the number of monitoring points grows , there is an increasing consumption of signal power with a consequent reduction of the DWDM system reach.
Standard: G.697
output: The choice of monitoring equipment positions in a DWDM system is influenced by several factors including the specific characteristics of the optical network element (ONE), such as the length of the system, number of spans, number of channels, and inaccessibility of the sites. Additionally, cost/benefit considerations play a significant role. It's important to note that as the number of monitoring points increases, there is a corresponding increase in signal power consumption, which can reduce the overall reach of the DWDM system.
